Award.AwardTitle: NetSE: Medium: Discovering Hyperbolic Metric Spaces Hidden beneath the Internet and Other Complex Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The lack of predictive power over complex systems, either designed by humans or evolved by nature, is a foundational problem in contemporary science. The Internet offers a paradigmatic example:
nothing in its architecture and design explains its complex large-scale structure. Many complex networks in nature share this peculiar structural character of the Internet, but they also manifest phenomenal behavior: they efficiently route information without any observable routing communication protocol. Hence, the main objective of this project is to explore the relationship between the structure and communication function of complex networks.

An international team of researchers assembled for this project includes computer scientists from the Cooperative Association for Internet Data Analysis (CAIDA) at the University of California San Diego, and physicists from the University of Barcelona, Spain. The project includes theoretical modeling and computer simulations to discover if the Internet 30-year old interdomain topology has naturally evolved toward a structure for which nature has superior routing technology.

The intellectual merit of this project is in the utilization of this natural routing technology for infinitely scalable Internet routing with minimal communication overhead. If successful, this project will solve a long-standing theoretical problem of constructing a maximally efficient algorithm for routing in complex networks. These results may help to remove serious scaling limitations within the existing Internet routing architecture.

The broader impact is in improving our knowledge of the basic principles of organization, function, and evolution of large-scale complex networks, transforming research on how to model, predict, and control them. The elucidation of fundamental connections between network structure and function has far-reaching impact on the study of many complex systems, including search engines, recommender and reputation systems, terrorist network modeling, cancer and brain research, protein folding, and drug design.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcome of this project is the discovery of hidden/latent hyperbolic metric spaces that underlie the Internet and many other real natural and designed networks, from social and biological networks to quantum networks in cosmology. The metric structure of these spaces explains high probability that two neighbors of the same node in a network are connected (the strong clustering property), while their hyperbolicity is responsible for the emergence of scale-free or fat-tailed degree distributions ubiquitously observed in real networks. The spatial distances between nodes in the hidden space were found to provide a universal measure of similarity between nodes.

The project developed a collection of tools to detect specific properties of a metric space underlying a given real network, and to map the network to its hidden space if it exists, inferring the latent spatial coordinates of each node. The application of these methods to real networks led to a realm of applications, including designing optimal (as scalable and efficient as theoretically possible) routing strategies for the Internet and other networks, developing link prediction methods outperforming existing state-of-the-art link prediction methods, identification of connections in the human brain critical for its function, and the discovery that the structure of these connections is nearly exactly as needed for optimal information routing in the brain.

The projected resulted in a host of software packages and datasets released to general public, and in more than twenty publications in high-impact journals and conferences in computer science (Transactions in Networking, INFOCOM, SIGMETRICS), physics (Physical Review Letters, Physical Review E, New Journal of Physics, Computer Physics Communications, Journal of Physics A: Mathematical and Theoretical), as well as in interdisciplinary journals (Nature, Nature Communications, Scientific Reports, PLOS ONE). Many of these publications were enthusiastically covered by the press worldwide (Time Magazine, Huffington Post, CBS, Register, Popular Science). The result that attracted most attention among the general public was the discovery that the rules of large-scale growth of the Internet, brain, and the causal set of the universe are asymptotically the same.

The project created vigorous research areas designing more efficient network mapping methods, extending them to wider classes of networks and simplicial complexes, predicting links in networks, and discovering functionally optimal network designs. The project also led to follow-on projects, ranging from mathematical research on deep connections between the discrete structure of random geometric graphs and the continuous structure of Riemannian and Lorentzian manifolds, to predicting the dynamics of real networks using their latent geometries, to the investigation of practical aspects of designing and deploying latent-geometric routing in future content-centric Internet architectures such as Named Data Networking.


Last Modified: 06/21/2016
Modified by: Dmitri Krioukov
